name: smoking
content:
smoking

noun
 
 
/ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
 
/ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. the activity or habit of smoking cigarettes, etc.
    • No Smoking (= for example, on a notice)
    • Smoking is not allowed in this theatre.
    • He's trying to give up smoking.
    • He's trying to stop smoking.
    • She started smoking at university.
    • to take up/quit smoking
    • the harmful effects of cigarette smoking
    • Your GP can provide advice on smoking cessation.
    • the introduction of the smoking ban in pubs, restaurants, and hotels
    compare non-smoking see also passive smoking
    Extra Examples
    • The campaign aims to reduce teen smoking.
    • The company has a strict no smoking policy.
    • The doctor advised me to cut down on smoking and alcohol.
    • a study of the harmful effects of smoking
    Topics Social issuesa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • chain
    • heavy
    • passive
    • …
    verb + smoking
    • start
    • take up
    • give up
    • …
    smoking + noun
    • habit
    • ban
    • room
    • …
    phrases
    • a ban on smoking
    • the dangers of smoking
    • the effects of smoking
    • …
    See full entry
See smoking in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee smoking in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: smoking

name: smoke
content:
smoke

verb
 
 
/sməʊk/
 
/sməʊk/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they smoke
 
/sməʊk/
 
/sməʊk/
he / she / it smokes
 
/sməʊks/
 
/sməʊks/
past simple smoked
 
/sməʊkt/
 
/sməʊkt/
past participle smoked
 
/sməʊkt/
 
/sməʊkt/
-ing form smoking
 
/ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
 
/ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1. ​
     
     [transitive, intransitive] to take smoke from a cigarette, pipe, etc. into your mouth and let it out again
    • Do you mind if I smoke?
    • You see kids openly smoking in the streets.
    • smoke something He was smoking a large cigar.
    • How many cigarettes do you smoke a day?
    • He was still smoking 20 cigarettes a day.
    • An old man smoking a pipe sat at a corner table.
    • to smoke marijuana/cannabis/pot
    Topics Social issuesa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • heavily
    • openly
    phrases
    • smoke like a chimney
    See full entry
  2. ​
     
     [intransitive] to use cigarettes, etc. in this way as a habit
    • Do you smoke?
    • She smokes heavily.
    • He smokes and drinks a lot.
    • I’ve never smoked.
    • You’re too young to smoke.
    • He smokes like a chimney (= a lot).
    see also chain-smokeTopics Social issuesa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • heavily
    • openly
    phrases
    • smoke like a chimney
    See full entry
  3. ​[intransitive] to produce smoke
    • smoking factory chimneys
    • the smoking remains of burnt-out cars
    • This fireplace smokes badly (= sends smoke into the room instead of up the chimney).
  4. ​[transitive, usually passive] to preserve meat or fish by hanging it in smoke from wood fires to give it a special taste
    • be smoked The ham is cured, then lightly smoked.
    • smoked salmon
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • heavily
    • lightly
    See full entry
    5. Word OriginOld English smoca (noun), smocian (verb), from the Germanic base of smēocan ‘emit smoke’; related to Dutch smook and German Schmauch.
Phrasal Verbs
  • smoke out
See smoke in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee smoke in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: non-smoking
content:
non-smoking

adjective
 
/ˌnɒn ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
 
/ˌnɑːn ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
 [usually before noun]
jump to other results
  1. ​
    (also no-smoking)
     (of a place) where people are not allowed to smoke
    • This is a non-smoking area.
    Topics Permission and obligationb1
  2. ​(of a person) who does not smoke
    • She's a non-smoking, non-drinking fitness fanatic.
    • The study aims to assess the effects of passive smoking on the non-smoking population.
Check pronunciation: non-smoking

name: non-smoking
content:
non-smoking

noun
 
/ˌnɒn ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
 
/ˌnɑːn ˈsməʊkɪŋ/
(also no-smoking)
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. ​the policy of not allowing people to smoke in a particular place
    • Non-smoking is now the norm in most workplaces.

name: smoking gun
content:
smoking gun

noun
 
/ˌsməʊkɪŋ ˈɡʌn/
 
/ˌsməʊkɪŋ ˈɡʌn/
[singular] (informal)
jump to other results
  1. ​something that seems to prove that somebody has done something wrong or illegal
    • This memo could be the smoking gun that investigators have been looking for.
    • There's no smoking gun that they have found to date.
See smoking gun in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: smoking gun

 [uncountable]

name: smoking ceremony
content:
smoking ceremony

noun
 
/ˈsməʊkɪŋ serəməni/
 
/ˈsməʊkɪŋ serəməʊni/
(Australian English)
jump to other results
  1. ​(in some Australian Aboriginal cultures) a ceremony in which smoke is used for ritual purposes, especially after death
    • In preparation for the “smoking ceremony”, they stoke a fire of tea tree and eucalyptus.
    • A “smoking ceremony” to cleanse the bones was held at Camp Coorong.
Check pronunciation: smoking ceremony

jump to other results
  1. ​a man’s comfortable jacket worn in the past, often made of velvet
